Short answer: a mix of realism and enthusiasm. Some genuinely exciting, non-“black hole crash” discoveries are plausibly imminent in the next 3–4 years; others are still long shots. Your roommate is not just being naive hype—but grad students do tend to emphasize the optimistic end of realistic forecasts.

Why that middle ground makes sense
- Instrument upgrades: Advanced LIGO, Virgo and KAGRA are getting sensitivity upgrades (A+ and incremental improvements). That raises detection rates, improves localizations and parameter accuracy, and makes fainter or rarer signals accessible.
- PTA progress: Pulsar Timing Arrays (NANOGrav, EPTA, PPTA and collaborators) have already seen a common-spectrum signal consistent with a stochastic background. A confident detection of a gravitational-wave background from supermassive black-hole binaries could be established within a few years.
- Mature science targets: More binary neutron star (BNS) and neutron-star–black-hole (NSBH) detections, better constraints on the neutron-star equation of state, improved population statistics (masses, spins, formation channels), and more multi-messenger opportunities are very plausible in that timeframe.
- Harder/longer-term targets: continuous waves from isolated spinning neutron stars, post-merger short-lived signals, direct detection of a primordial/cosmological background, or routine detection of exotic sources (cosmic strings, primordial black-hole mergers) are much less likely in 3–4 years.

Practical short forecast (3–4 year horizon)
- High likelihood: many more compact-binary detections (BBH, BNS, NSBH) and better population constraints; at least some multi-messenger events if an electromagnetic counterpart is found for a nearby BNS.
- Medium likelihood: a robust PTA detection/confirmation of a stochastic supermassive-black-hole-binary background (this is one of the most realistic non-BBH-merge “big” results in the near term).
- Medium/low likelihood: an incontrovertible detection of an intermediate-mass black hole merger or continuous waves from a known pulsar—possible but not guaranteed.
- Low likelihood: detection of a cosmological/inflationary background, cosmic-string bursts, or LISA-class space-based sources (LISA is planned for the 2030s).

How to be supportive without fanning hype
- Ask specifics: “What exactly do you think will be discovered, and which instrument will find it?” That lets them explain the realistic chain (detector upgrade → increased sensitivity → specific observable).
- Show curiosity: “How would that change our understanding?” helps them connect the hype to real science.
- Gentle reality checks: “That would be amazing—what are the main factors that could stop that from happening?” invites a sober view without killing enthusiasm.
- Celebrate the wins: when the field posts incremental results (rate updates, better localizations, PTA papers), acknowledge them—those are the building blocks of big discoveries.

Bottom line: your roommate’s excitement is rooted in real, planned experimental progress, particularly the PTA front and ground-detector upgrades. Some of the headline “beyond black hole crashes” outcomes are quite plausible soon, while others remain speculative and would take longer. Supporting her enthusiasm while asking for specifics is a good, honest way to engage.

text: I'm producing a documentary about gravitational waves. My science advisor wants to include a whole segment on exotic new sources LIGO might find soon, but honestly it feels like speculative filler. We have limited runtime. Is this worth including or should I focus on what we've actually detected?
proposition: LIGO or another gravitational wave detector will observe gravitational waves from a new type of source (not binary mergers) before 2030.
response_text:
Short answer: prioritize the firm detections for your main runtime, but keep a brief, tightly framed “looking ahead” segment (or a web/bonus deep-dive) on the most plausible exotic sources. That gives your advisor something substantive while keeping the documentary grounded and trustworthy.

Why — pros and cons
- Pros of including exotic sources
  - Inspires wonder and stakes: shows science is active and that LIGO could upend physics.
  - Connects gravitational waves to big questions (dark matter, early Universe, new particles).
  - Gives your advisor a platform and can make the documentary feel forward-looking.
- Cons
  - Risk of appearing speculative or filler if presented without clear context.
  - Uses limited runtime that could strengthen the core story (what’s been actually detected, how detection works, human stories).
  - May confuse general viewers if you don’t clearly label speculation and likelihood.

Practical recommendation
- Make confirmed detections the backbone of the film (binary black hole mergers, binary neutron star + multi-messenger, detector story, data/analysis human element).
- Reserve a short “frontiers” segment (3–6 minutes in a typical 60–90 minute doc) that:
  - Clearly labels material as speculative but scientifically motivated.
  - Focuses on 3–4 highest-payoff, reasonably plausible exotic targets (see shortlist below).
  - Uses the segment to explain why these searches matter, what they would prove, and how LIGO would recognize them.
- Alternate: if runtime is extremely tight, omit from the main film but produce a director’s-cut/online bonus episode devoted to exotic sources. That keeps the main narrative tight while satisfying the advisor and curious viewers.

How to make the “exotic” content good (not filler)
- Be explicit about probability and uncertainty: words like “possible,” “hypothetical,” and “under active search” — don’t hype.
- Emphasize process: how scientists look for these signals, what a detection would mean, and what limits so far tell us.
- Pair each topic with a human voice: an enthusiastic theorist (your advisor) plus an empirical skeptic/observer to keep balance.
- Use striking visuals and simple metaphors to make unfamiliar ideas accessible.
- Pick topics that connect to big questions (dark matter, particle physics, cosmology) so the payoff is clear.

Shortlist of high-value exotic topics to consider (with why and how LIGO would see them)
- Intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs, ~100–10^5 Msun)
  - Why: bridge formation channels, seed black holes for galaxies.
  - Signature: high-mass mergers with low-frequency chirps; plausible given current detectors’ sensitivity growth.
  - Plausibility: already some candidates; reasonable to include.
- Primordial black holes (PBHs)
  - Why: potential dark matter candidate, ties to early Universe.
  - Signature: unusual mass distributions or merger rates; sub-solar-mass detections would be a smoking gun.
  - Plausibility: constrained but not entirely ruled out; high storytelling value.
- Boson clouds / ultralight particles (axion-like)
  - Why: would reveal new particle physics from black hole superradiance.
  - Signature: continuous, nearly monochromatic gravitational waves from boson clouds around spinning BHs.
  - Plausibility: actively searched for; high scientific payoff if found.
- Neutron star instabilities / continuous waves
  - Why: probes nuclear physics and interior structure of neutron stars.
  - Signature: long-lived, nearly monochromatic signals; different data-analysis methods than bursts.
  - Plausibility: observationally challenging but credible search program.
- Eccentric or multi-body mergers, hierarchical mergers
  - Why: tells you about dense cluster dynamics and formation channels.
  - Signature: non-standard waveform morphologies (eccentricity, repeated bursts).
  - Plausibility: expected in some astrophysical environments; LIGO already looks for this.
- Cosmic strings (least likely but high drama)
  - Why: would be direct evidence of fundamental high-energy physics/topological defects.
  - Signature: short, high-amplitude bursts or a stochastic background with distinctive spectrum.
  - Plausibility: more speculative — include only if framed properly as long-shot.

Suggested runtime allocation (example, 90-minute doc)
- Core: confirmed science, instrument, human stories — ~70–80 minutes.
- Frontiers block: 4–6 minutes, 3–4 topics, each ~60–90 seconds plus brief expert soundbites.
- Optional web/bonus: deep dives (10–20 minutes total) for audience members who want more.

Sample framing lines you could use on-camera (concise, honest)
- “So far, LIGO and its partners have measured gravitational waves from colliding black holes and neutron stars. But physicists are also hunting for stranger signals — possibilities that would rewrite parts of cosmology and particle physics. These searches are active, exciting, and still speculative. Here are the best-motivated things they might find next.”
Use this or something similar to set viewer expectations.

If you’re worried about your advisor feeling shortchanged
- Offer them a clear slot in the frontiers block where they can explain one favorite idea in an impactful, concise way.
- Or propose creating a short companion piece (web extra, podcast) hosted or narrated by them to explore exotic ideas in depth.

Bottom line: don’t give up the solid storytelling time that demonstrates what we actually know. But do include a short, well-framed frontier segment (or an online extra) that showcases the plausible, high-payoff exotic searches — it keeps the documentary forward-looking without turning it into speculation.
